title: At the end, what happened to the Roman Empire? - Quora

response.answer_text: The question here is what do you mean by “at the end”. When is the end of the Roman Empire? In the other answers you see many different viewpoints. There’s the conventional popular idea that the Roman Empire ended in the 5th century when the last emperor was deposed by Odoacer. There’s the idea that that didn’t mean the end, and the institutions simply faded away. There’s the idea that the Roman Empire actually continued until 1453 when the Ottomans took Constantinople. There’s the idea that the Ottoman Empire was the continuation of the Roman Empire and therefore it only fell in 1922. All those are correct in a certain way (even if the last one is stretching it a bit, since the Kayser-i-Rûm title hasn’t really been used in a long time). But there’s a lot more! You can say the Empire ended with Octavian winning the civil war, since the Republic, which was the defining ideology of Rome, was dead. But the Empire lived on, of course.You can say the Empire ended with Diocletian, who did away with the last vestiges of the republican pretense (end of the principate). But again, the Empire lived on, restrengthened by Diocletians reforms.You can say the Empire ended when Odoacer kicked Romulus out. But the Empire survived in the East, and Odoacer even acknowledged the Emperor as his overlord.You can say the Empire ended when they couldn’t effectively regain control of the Western portions of it, but in Constantinople the Empire survived. Even more, some Frankish guy got himself crowned Emperor, and now we had TWO Roman Empires. One of them was even Holy!You can say the Empire ended when the fourth crusade took Constantinople. But even then the Empire survived in exile in Nicaea. What’s more, the crusader state itself was a form of the Roman Empire. So now there’s three (the HRE is still alive and kicking). And besides, the Nicaeans came back.You can say the Empire ended when the Ottomans took Constantinople. But Mehmet himself would disagree, and say that he was now the Kayser-i-Rûm, the Caesar of Rome, and that the Empire survived under him. Also, the HRE is still there. And also, the Russians were claiming to be the Third Rome. So now you have a Roman Empire in Germany, a Roman Empire in Turkey, and a Roman Empire in Russia. Not in Rome, though, why would a Roman Empire control Rome? That makes no sense.You can say that the Empire ended when Napoleon disolved the HRE, or when the Ottoman Empire fell after WWI, or when the Russian Empire fell during the Russian Revolution. But other than the HRE, those have clear successor states. So you can say that the Roman Empire still exists as Turkey. Or as Russia. Or maybe as the Vatican City. Or maybe as Germany. Or maybe as somebody else said, as the European Union.Yes, I know, most of these is just stretching it for fun. But the point is that “at the end”, for the Roman Empire, is not a very definitive point in time. It’s not like, for example, the USSR, where we can find a date when it ceased to exist, and we can say “on this date, the USSR existed, and the next day it didn’t”. It doesn’t really work like that for the Roman Empire.

I faded away. Slowly its institutions and culture died out or were assimilated by surrounding cultures.  The Roman Empire of antiquity was strictly speaking not conquered in its entirety by a foreign power. Pieces were taken, revolutions undermined the power of institutions until not much was left to be called an Empire. But so much of its identity lived on in other places that its hard to define an end to it. An amusing anecdote given by somebody on Quora helps to illustrate that: When Greek soldiers came to an island in 1913 ceded to Greece by the Ottoman Empire, the children came looking at the "Greeks". The soldiers asked: "If we are Greeks. What are you?" . The children answered: We are Romans (Romaoi).

It was dissolved in 1922, shortly after WWI. Its last emperor, Sultan Mehmed VI resigned (who had inherited the title all the way back to 1453 when Mehmed the Conqueror had taken it from the east Roman emperors).

The Roman Empire is still very much alive though the name has changed to suit the modern politics. The combined European Union potential comprises the the strength of the Roman Empire and is is still very much dealing the same way as the subsided Empire they are still rooted into. Even adapting to Christianity has not erased the effect of the Roman civilization on the Western cultural and social norms. So my answer is that the Roman Empire has not seen the END yet.

It was ended when the army of the Ottoman Sultanate stormed and took it's capital, Constantinople, from the Romans in May 1453, after approximately a month of siege against the exhausted and depopulated remains of the City. They destroyed the defenders, looted the city, enslaved much of what was left of it's population, and killed the last Roman Emperor, Constantine XI Dragases-Palaeologus, in a last stand at the St. Romanus gate, between the outer and inner walls. In the ensuing years the last independent and scattered remains of the ancient Roman provinces of Armenia and Hellas were subsumed into the Ottoman whole, and all the Romans became subjects of that Empire.
